Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Testing the Potential of Pathogenic Fungi to Control the Diversity, Distribution, and Abundance of Tree Species in a Neotropical Forest Community
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will integrate taxonomic, genetic, and functional approaches in a combination of observations and experiments to test the Enemy Susceptibility Hypothesis (ESH) for tropical tree diversity and rarity. This hypothesis predicts that rare tree species will have a greater percentage of hollow-trunk trees, harbor more pathogenic fungal species, and also share more of these pathogens with other tree species, than common tree species. At forest plots on Barro Colorado Island, Panama, researchers will survey all trees, sample and culture fungi, and determine which fungal species are present on which trees. Fungal pathogenicity and specificity will be tested, and the mechanistic basis for why some fungal species have broader host ranges than others will be explored through comparative genomic sequence analyses.

If the Enemy Susceptibility Hypothesis holds up to these tests, it may prove to be a general explanation for the high diversity and rarity of tree species in tropical forests worldwide. The project will also include participation of high school and college students, as well as high school science teachers from California, Georgia, and Panama. The participants will travel to Panama and take a two-week field-biology course that will expose them to the exciting new research questions in ecology and evolution being opened for study by the high-throughput DNA sequencing technologies now available. This course will be taught each year for the first three years of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project tests a mechanistic hypothesis for why so many tropical tree species are rare (occur at low population density) in a well-studied tropical forest on Barro Colorado Island (BCI), Panama. Specifically, we are testing the Enemy Susceptibility Hypothesis that rare tree species are more susceptible to fungal attack and share more fungal pathogens with other host species than do common tree species, and so they are rare because they have fewer safe places to grow where they can avoid infection. Our preliminary analyses of field data collected during this project showed that the likelihood of heart rot in trees > 20 cm increases with the size of the tree, from about 10% of trees at 20-cm diameter to 60% among the largest trees and that species vary greatly in how susceptible to decay they are: 23% of species showed almost no decay whereas 9% of the species lost more than half their basal area to heart rot.  In support of the Enemy Susceptibility hypothesis, our results also showed that stems of rare tree species were about twice as likely as more common species to have significant amounts of heart rot and to have more severe heart rot. Molecular analyses of wood core samples collected from infected trees are continuing, and we will use species identification of fungi in each wood core sample to test the remaining idea that rare trees harbor a greater number of diverse fungal pathogens.  

Another goal of our project was to train a number of young scientists in the field and molecular techniques that we used throughout the project to collect data. To achieve this goal, we trained one post-doctoral scientist, three graduate students, five post-baccalaureate researchers, and eleven undergraduate researchers. We also conducted two workshops in Panama where we invited and trained eight American and Panamanian high school students, nine college students or recent graduates, one graduate student, six high school teachers, and one faculty member at a primarily undergraduate-serving institution.  We also incorporated an REU project to our research that additionally trained two students and a faculty member at a Hispanic Serving community college. We used our tomography experience to develop a quarter-long class-based research project in California, and two students prepared senior theses building from that work. Finally, we used our tomography experience to develop a year-long professional training program for the staff of the environmental management program in Panama City, which has grown into an ongoing research collaboration in urban forest health while also  contributing to a major municipal effort in management of urban street and park trees throughout Panama City.
